qas.question: What are the hairs on ctenophores called?
Comb like bands of cilia are called what?
What does ctenophore mean in Greek?
How many types of cilia are there?
How long can the cillia grow on ctenophores?
What do cilia use their bodies for?
What are the bodies of cilia also called?
What kind of animals are cilia considered?

context: Ranging from about <b5_0>1 millimeter (0.039 in) to 1.5 meters (4.9 ft)<b5_0/> in size, ctenophores are the largest <b8_0>non-colonial<b8_0/> animals that use <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>cilia<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> ("hairs") as <a1_1>their main <a1_0>method of <a1_2><b6_0>locomotion<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. Most species have <b4_0>eight<b4_0/> strips, called comb rows, that run the length of their bodies and bear comb-like bands of cilia, called <b7_0>"<a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>ctenes<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>,"<b7_0/> stacked along the comb rows so that when the cilia beat, those of each comb touch the comb below. The name "ctenophora" means "<a3_0><a3_2>comb-bearing<a3_2/><a3_0/>", from the Greek κτείς (stem-form κτεν-) meaning <a3_1>"comb" and the Greek suffix -φορος meaning "carrying"<a3_1/>.
